152.content:
You're name is Tim, and you are a senior in high school having a rough, time, but none of that matters right now because it's Friday, and you'll be home soon! You were sitting in class and lamenting the fact that your math teacher, Mr. Edmund, seemed to drone on and on about these things called imagineary numbers, the utility of which baffeled you a bit anyway, but apparently the state school board had decided they were important. You watch the hands of the clock turn all-too-slowly toward your freedom...fifteen minutes, then ten...then five...DAMMIT! At about the five-minute mark, you hear the PA come on and the booming voice of the school principal fills the hall, "This is Mr. White speaking, and I need Timothy Gately to report to my office immidiately.

Dejected and figuring that this is going to both delay your leaving school and ensure that your weekend would suck, you get up from your dsk and make your way to the door and try to ignore the snickers from fellow students who take some pleasure in seeing someone else suffer. Walking down the hallway toward the principal's office, you wonder what your could possibly have done. You've been having a bit of trouble lately, but you're certainly not a trouble-maker...why would White want to see you?

You turn and go through the doorway into a sort of small complex full of offices--some for guidence councellors, one for the school nurse, and various others. Since it's the end of the day, all of them are packing up to go home, but one of the secretaries recognizes you and motions you to go ahead and go into the principal's office. You lightly knock on the door to get his attention.

Mr. White is a portly man, about 55 and balding with a few haphazzardly positioned strands of hair here and there. He is friendly with students, but of course a call to the principal's office is never really a great thing. He is wearing a white suit shirt which seems to struggle containing his potbelly, he has on dress pants and a belt that is buckled tightly around his expanded wasteline. He is probably about 5"8,' and many students joke that his width is only slightly smaller, but hey he's a nice guy.

Upon hearing the knock, he startles a bit and looks up. Seeing you, he smiles and waves you in, "Ah yes, Timothy, come in, come in," motioning for you to approach by wiggling his stubbly fingers, "close the door, please," he adds. You take a seat in the chair close to his desk.

"Tim," he begins, "the reason I wanted to speak with you is that I'm told your grades have been slipping, and we want to make sure everything is al right." "Yes, Mr. White, I'm fine, but I just have a few classes this semester that aren't my thing; I never liked math, and this semester I've got a trig class," you explain.

"I see," White says, "Well, everybody has weaknesses, but this quarter seems especially tough for you, and not just in math...English too, and history. We have a way that might help you," he offers. "It would require a great committment on your part, but if you work hard, you can get into a good college, and with the economy the way it is, you'll need that education."

"Well I suppose it would be great if I could do better," you admit, hoping that you won't end up regretting it.

White lights up, "That's the spirit, my boy!" he exclaims, smiling with such vigor that all his chins jiggle at the same time. "What if I told you we could help you, but it would be an intensive program, one that we've not tried before, one that would require a lot of work at home?"

"I'll do it," you agree, not wanting to see any more sad faces from your mom when she gets grade cards.

"Wonderful!," White says, and he prys himself out of his chair pushing it back to make room for his belly so as not to knock over all the crap on the desk. A bit suprised, you stand as well, smiling back at him.

Suddenly, White stops smiling, he seems almost to be feeling light-headed and falls backward very limply onto his chair, out cold. The amazing thing, though, is that in his place is Ms. Holsten! She is 25 years old, about 5"7' with wide hips and a round ass barely encased by tight dark pants, and she has on a thin white blouse that struggles to contain her boobs. She is also one of the kindest women you know.

"Whoa...whoa, what the hell!" you say in disbelief, staggering back.

"Tim it's all right," she says, "it's just me, and I'm doing this to help you."

Amazed, you demand, "How did you do that? Were you...inside....."

Holsten finishes, "...his body. Yes, I was inside Mr. White. You don't have to understand now, but just know that I can posses people. I took over his body to make sure you were willing to put in the work I have in mind, Tim, and you and I don't get a lot of time to talk in class." She goes on, "I am doing this tohelp you raise you grades; It's very important to me that you do well, because I care about you a lot," she says, blushing a little and looking down.

"What I want to do is go home and help you," she says.

"What...what do you mean go home and help me?" you ask.

"Well, you'll need help to get your grades up, and with my power I can go home and spend time studying with you, time I could not spend with you at school. I can posses someone close to you, and I'll use that body to help you learn your stuff."

Amazed at the committment this demonstrates from Holsten herself, and happy that she cares so much for you, you smile at her and say meekly, "Ok....ok you can help me."

She smiles and looks relieved, "Oh thank you Tim, you don't know how much I want to see you succeed. Now, how do we get home, to your house I mean. I'll need to borrow someone's body while we get there, it'd be odd if a teacher traveled to your home with you in the open."

"Well," you pondered, "yeah I guess you'll have to posses someone else, but who?"

Ms. Holsten thought for a minute, and she came up with three choices:

"I could posses the Vice Principal, Mrs. Waters; I know she lives just down the street from you."

"I could jump into you're friend Jimmy's mother; she's here for a Parent-Teacher Assocition meeting; people have seen her with you lots of times, and I could drive you home."

"I could use your body, Tim, I swear I wouldn't do anything bad, and I'll let you remember the whole thing, but you have to trust me."

1522112.content:
'Hey, Tim, have you seen my mom, she's meant to be picking me up but I've signed up for extra soccer practice and-oh, she's here.' Jimmy was standing at the door. His eyes moved from you to his mother and when they saw her unbuttoned blouse and leaning over the desk, he arched his eyebrows. 'Hey, so, um, what's going on here?'

Holsten gave a sly smirk at you, then stood back from the desk and straightened up.

'Oh, it's nothing, Jimmy, I was um, just telling Tim that he needs to take a lift home with us today.' She shifted her head so that Jimmy couldn't see her wink at you. 'According to Ms. Holsten, both of you boys aren't doing well in her class and she's asked me to make sure that you actually complete the revision module from today's module.'

'What are you talking about, I'm acing her class.' Jimmy said defensively.

'Don't you dare think of lying to me, child!' Holsten roared with such parental authority that Jimmy actually flinched and stepped backwards. 'I know that you're doing terrible in m-Ms. Holsten's class. So, you are most certainly not going to soccer practice, instead, you are going to go get your bags and books and then meet me and Tim in the car in no more than five minutes time from now. Have I made myself clear?'

'Yes, ma'am,' Jimmy mumbled.

'Sorry? Didn't quite catch that?' Holsten theatrically put a cupped hand to her ear.

'I said, "Yes, ma'am!"'

'Good boy,' Holsten said cheerfully. 'Run along then, you've got five minutes.'

Jimmy shot a sullen look at the two of you and then turned and left. After a few seconds of silence, making sure that Jimmy was long gone Holsten burst into great peals of laughter.

'Oh my god,' she said as she gasped for breath between laughs. 'Did you see the look on his face?'

You hadn't seen the look on Jimmy's face, except for at the very beginning and the very end. During the middle, and as soon as
Holsten had started chewing Jimmy out, you'd felt a stirring within your pants.

'Oh gods, please, no, please, no,' you'd thought to yourself as you heard the strictness in Holsten's stolen voice. If the scene had played on any longer, there would have been no way of concealing your erection. As it was, you were now left at half mast and hoping Holsten wouldn't notice.

'I hope that's not the full package,' her laughs began anew. She'd noticed.

She leaned over and gently patted your semi, 'All in good time, little one.' She straightened on and re-buttoned her blouse, then picked up her bag and walked over to the classroom door, 'Come on, Tim, we need to find Carol's car and wait for Jimmy.'

You said nothing, your head was spinning. Was any of this really happening? What even was happening? Numbly, without consciously deciding to, you followed Holsten out of the classroom.

----

'Where is that boy?' Holsten drummed her fingers repeatedly across the steering wheel. 'I did say five minutes, didn't I? I'm sure I did.'

You just nod from your position in the back of the car. You knew that if you were sat in the front seat that Jimmy would have just made you get out and sit in the back anyway, and the half formed erection hadn't gone away yet. He'd definitely notice it this time, if you had to change seats. You shifted uncomfortably in your seat and as you did, you looked up into the rear-view mirror and saw Holsten's eyes looking at you. Maybe it was because you rarely spoke to Jimmy's mother, and whenever you did, she had wide, open eyes instead of the narrow and calculating look that Holsten had brought to her face, but something about the eyes didn't look right. That's when it hit you.

'You have blue eyes,' you said.

'Yes, and?'

'I'm pretty sure that Mrs. O'Connor has green eyes.'

'Oh, Tim, dear, I never thought you'd be on those boys who are always gazing deeply into the eyes of their friends parents...'

Your face went beet red as you stammered whilst trying to refute her allegation. She gave a serious look at you in the mirror, and then laughed again.

'I'm just joking, Tim,' she slapped the steering wheel a couple of times. She paused and looked at her fingers and went silent for a moment. Then, in a quiet voice, she said, 'I'm not a fidgeter, I never fidget. I'm also not normally this jokey and sarcastic....or this,' she blushed slightly, 'this...mmhmm, well....I think being in another person's body is giving me some of their characteristics....'

You both jumped as the passenger door suddenly opened and Jimmy slung first his bag, then himself, into the seat.

Holsten snapped out of her reverie.

'How long did I say to take, young man?' She'd switched back into her faux strict parent mode. You squirmed uncomfortably in your seat.

'Five minutes,' Jimmy muttered under his breath.

'Yes, five minutes, and how long were you?'

'More'n five minutes,' Jimmy turned his head away from you and his mother.

'That's right, more than five minutes. You've been at least,' Holsten theatrically calculated out loud, 'carry the one, adjust for daylight savings time, I'd make it to be at least twenty minutes. Wouldn't you agree, Tim?'

You gave a non committal grunt as you lifted your leg slightly to conceal the growing erection.

'Yes, twenty whole minutes, probably even a bit longer. So, when we get in, I want you to go straight to your room, Jimmy.'

'But I-'

'No buts, mister, straight to your bedroom, do not pass go, do not collect 200 dollars,' Holsten grinned in the rear view mirror. 'Me and Tim will set up the revision lesson with the notes given to me by Ms. Holsten and then, when we're ready, we'll call you down and we'll get started.'

'But I-'

'I said "no buts", and I mean it! Say another word and I'll make you go straight back to your room after we finish the lesson as well!'

Jimmy opened his mouth to protest but thought better of it. Holsten smirked and put the car in gear.

'Good, glad to hear it.'

She reversed out of the parking space and drove the car slowly through the parking lot. Jimmy sighed and rolled down his window.

'It's freezing,' Holsten said, shivering slightly, 'why are you rolling down your window.'

'Because I hate the smell of smoke and this get's rid of some of it.'

'What smoke?'

'Your smoke. You always smoke when you're driving? Or have you finally given up, like I'm always asking you to?'

You didn't know that Mrs O'Connor smoked. Apparently, neither did Ms. Holsten. You watched as she slowed the car to a crawl as she fished through Mrs O'Connor's bag and pulled out a crumpled, half full packet of cigarettes and a plastic lighter. You saw her eyes widen. Ms. Holsten was one of the anti-smoking "champions", as the school called it. She'd delivered numerous assemblies about the dangers of smoking. She was always on smoking duty, which involved going around and finding the kids who were sneaking smokes and giving them detention. She was the teacher who'd written the Health and Social Education lesson plan for the entire school on the subject. The thought of her, even in someone else's body, smoking, was such a strange one, such a forbidden one, that you, you...

'This is why I've been fidgeting so much,' Holsten thought to herself. She brought the car to a complete stop. She looked down at the packet in her fingers, in Mrs O'Connor's fingers.

'I shouldn't, I don't want to....but,' her mind raced. Something within her longed for it. 'It's not my body, it's hers. It is her vice. Her addiction. She slipped a cigarette out of the packet and held it up to her eyes.

'Just an experiment, that's all it is, just an experiment whilst I'm in this body.' She was trying to rationalise but knew that there was no rational decision being made here. She was a slave to this bodies addiction so long as she was in said body. She put the cigarette between her lips, and fumbled with the lighter. One, two, three, the flame sprung to life as she thumbed the dial. She held it to the cigarette, watching the tip flare and catch alight as she breathed in.

'Oh my god, that's wonderful,' she thought as she exhaled. The nicotine flooded through her body and she felt a knot in her head, which she hadn't even realised she had had, untangle and melt away. She left the cigarette between her lips as she again put the car into gear and drove out of the car park.

Meanwhile, in the back seat, your erection was now full and complete. You hitched your leg higher still, and leaned as far back into the seat as you could and thanked the gods that neither Jimmy, who was all but hanging out of the car window, or Holsten, who was too wrapped up at finding out how to make her new body feel so much better, were paying any attention to you. You hoped that the drive would be a long one to give the erection a chance to fade away.

15221122.content:
Thankfully, the drive was a good half an hour and your erection was long gone by the time the car you were in pulled into the O’Connor’s driveway. You could feel a slight damp patch of shame in your pants but that, at least, would be invisible to the eye of Jimmy and Holsten. The drive itself had been immeasurably awkward; Jimmy, having been scolded upon entering the car, had more or less contented himself with staring silently out of the car window, straining against the seatbelt as Holsten chained cigarette after cigarette. She’d gone through at least five in the half hour long drive, but she too had been silent. The novelty of the act had worn off fast as you were sat behind her and had been caught in the billowing clouds of tobacco smoke. It was with much relief that when you stepped out of the O’Connor’s car, you gulped down as big a lungful of fresh air as you could. You looked over and saw Jimmy making eye contact with you for the first time since getting in the car, he had a very much “I have to deal with this every day” kind of look to them, but then he seemed to remember he was being sullen and so he turned away quickly.

         Holsten closed and locked her car door then absentmindedly rooted through Mrs O’Connor’s bag for the front door keys. When she’d located them and put them into the keyhole to open the door, Jimmy pushed past her and all but ran up the stairs.

         ‘Hey, watch it, mister!’ Holsten called after him.

         ‘I’m grounded, remember, I’m just doing what you told me to!’ Jimmy shouted back in a petulant tone. There were some thunderous footfalls from the upstairs hallway as he stomped along to his bedroom and then a loud slam as his door was lashed close. Holsten looked at you and rolled her eyes theatrically, then stood to the side and beckoned you into the house.

         ‘Come on in then, Mr Gately,’ she said in a mock refined voice.

         You wished that you had a witty comeback but something twitched down below again and so you just mumbled “thanks” and entered the house. Holsten led you into the living room and waved an arm in gesture:

         ‘Pick a seat, any seat,’ she then disappeared out of another door, leaving you standing alone in Jimmy’s living room. You’d only been to his house a few times before, and you’d never been in the living room, instead, you and Jimmy had just darted up to his room, almost as quickly as he himself had just ran up there today. You saw some pictures of the O’Connor family above the mantelpiece and you wandered over to them. They were all old pictures. Jimmy was in a few of them, but even in the clearly most recently taken one, he was still only an infant. He was sat on Mr O’Connor’s lap in most of them. You had only ever seen Jimmy’s father once and you’d been terrified out of your wits as the man was a giant. Even in the pictures, he looked almost comically oversized, as if someone had photoshopped him to be half again as big as he should be. He was wearing a suit in most of the pictures and the suit seemed to be threatening to burst at the seams. His black, bushy beard even then was speckled with a few streaks of silvery grey and his dark eyes pierced through you.

         ‘He’s also incredibly well endowed,’ Holsten said from behind you. You jumped a little as you hadn’t heard her re-enter the room and you spun around to see her carrying a tray with two mugs of tea and some biscuits. ‘I wonder what he would say and do if he found you hear, lusting after your friend’s mother. His wife?’ She laughed as she put the tray down on a table and then sat herself down on the settee. She picked up one of the mugs and gave a tentative sip.

         ‘Mm, still too hot.’ She put the mug down, then reached into her pockets and took out a packet of cigarettes. She lit one as she stared at you with a calculating look.

         You moved away from the mantelpiece and sat down opposite her, you reached over and picked up your own mug.

         ‘I’ve been thinking, Tim,’ she leant forward. ‘This is all a bit weird, isn’t it?’

         You gulped hard, ‘I don’t…. what do you mean?’

         ‘I mean, I think I’ve gone the wrong way about this whole thing.’ She put the cigarette down into an ashtray, then she grabbed either side of her head and pulled forward. There was a soft, somewhat squelching noise, and then your eyes widened as Holsten’s head, her real head that is, detached itself from Mrs O’Connor’s, whose head drooped forward then lolled like a ragdoll’s in front of her.

         ‘I have a confession to make,’ Holsten bit her bottom lip. ‘I did this whole thing to get close to you. I said it was to help you with your lessons, and I do mean that, I want you to do well but the ulterior motive was just to spend some time with you like that.’
You couldn’t believe what you were hearing. The weird flirting, you thought had just been teasing, but no, Ms Holsten, the hottest teacher in the school, was actually interested in you.

         ‘I mean, I’m only, what, eight years older than you, and now, by taking over Carol O’Connor’s body, I’ve at least doubled that, I’ve gone the wrong way haven’t I?’

         Wait. What was she suggesting?

         ‘I have her memories, some of them anyway, so long as I’m in her body, and I can see how paranoid Mr O’Connor can be, especially when strapping young lads such as yourself are alone with his wife. And he’s not entirely wrong to be so….’ Holsten shook her head which made Mrs O’Connor’s head flop around almost comically.

         ‘So,’ she looked up at you, a serious look on her face, ‘What do you say I ditch this ride and we go find a better one?’
Your head was spinning with possibilities and your thoughts ranged from the trite to the spectacular. She could be anyone, do anything, and she was offering to do it with you.

         ‘Tim? Tim, is that you, what’s going on? Why can’t I move my arms, my legs, what’s going on?’

         Both you and Holsten stared in horror as Carol O’Connor’s head stirred feebly. She could only move it slightly up and down and Tim could see that her green eyes looked terrified.

         ‘Why can’t I move, I can feel someone behind me, who’s behind me? Tim, what’s going on?’ Her voice quavered as she spoke. Holsten moved Mrs O’Connor’s arms and quickly pushed her own head back into Carol’s. Carol’s face gave a slight spasm and her eyes turned the bright blue of Holsten’s own.

         ‘Oh god,’ you said, as you stood up in a panic. ‘Oh god, is she going to remember that?’

         ‘I don’t know…’ Holsten said slowly. She nervously picked up the still smouldering cigarette and took a big drag. She held the cigarette to her face and looked at it thoughtfully, then, at length, she said ‘I think I can make her think it was a dream, but we need to leave, now.’

         You nodded. All your thoughts about the possibilities Holsten could achieve had come to a crashing halt with Mrs O’Connor’s scared voice.

         ‘Okay, here’s what we’re going to do, you leave, now, and start making your way home. I’ll go tell Jimmy that you had to leave, family emergency or whatever, and then I’ll go put Mrs O’Connor to bed. Then I’ll leave and we’ll sort this out tomorrow.’

         Numbly, you nodded. You felt as if you should say something, but then you were pretty much concentrating on keeping your knees from buckling. Holsten grabbed you by the elbow and quickly shepherded you to the door and out of the house. It was only when you were stood outside, about to walk home that you stopped to think, ‘what did she mean about sorting this out tomorrow?’

choices: Confront Ms Holsten (either with or without Jimmy)
Keep it a secret, you find yourself oddly liking the drama
1522112221.content:
You didn’t hear from Holsten at all over the weekend. You’d assumed that she’d try and contact you in some way, either by somewhat traditional methods or by possessing one of your friends or family. If she had taken the latter option, she hadn’t made herself known to you. The thought was somehow both terrifying and arousing, and it had certainly kept you on your toes both in private and public situations.

         Now that Monday had rolled around, you were flipping between anxiety and giddiness, because you knew that today you would definitely be seeing Holsten, even if it was only at the front of the classroom. You practically jumped out of bed when the alarm went off, and was showered and dressed in record time. You were sat at the family table, eating a slice of toast, when your mother, Rebecca, walked in, yawning widely and reaching for a mug. You barely noticed that she’d come in, however, and when you heard her speaking to you, you jumped slightly.

         ‘I said, “Are you alright, Tim?”’, she said, taking a sip of her coffee. ‘You’re practically bouncing in your seat, and your face is all sweaty?’

         ‘I, um,’ you tried to think of an excuse but came up with nothing.

         ‘Here, let me have a feel of your forehead,’ Rebecca said. She put her drink down and walked over to you and put the back of her hand above your eyes.

         ‘Hmm,’ she said. ‘It feels as though you’re burning up ever so slightly, maybe you’ve got a flu coming on. Perhaps you shouldn’t go into school today.’

         For a brief second, your mind flashed and you thought to yourself, ‘Ah-hah! So, Holsten’s taken over my mom’s body and is trying to get me to stay home from school!’ But as quickly as the thought came it was banished as you looked at your mother’s eyes and saw that they were their usual hazel colour.

         You jumped back in your seat, pushing it away and standing up.

         ‘No, mum, I’m okay, I can’t miss school today,’ You were already marching out of the room and missed her saying something. ‘Can’t hear you, mum, love you, see you this afternoon!’

         You slipped out of the front door and were halfway down the street before you realised that you’d left the house a good three quarters of an hour earlier than you normally would have. You looked up at the feeble morning sun trying to break through the grey clouds. It was barely even dawn, you realised, and the world looked monochrome and desaturated. You slowed your walk to a trudge and hoped it would compensate but it didn’t help very much, and you still arrived at the school half an hour early. The school gates were open but the main building doors were still locked and so you found yourself wandering around the various buildings looking for somewhere to be open so you could get in and sit down somewhere inside. Finally, you found an open building, the cafeteria, and as you opened the door you were met with twenty or so other students sat in a semi-circle, being lectured to by Mr White who stopped his narration when he saw you.

         ‘Ah, Mr Timothy Gately, we didn’t expect you here today,’ Mr White said in an overblown and pompous voice. ‘You’re just in time to join our pre-school day calculus revision! I know you’ve been having trouble in some of your classes, especially with derivatives, so you might get some help out of this.’

         You opened your mouth to say something but any argument you may have had died on your tongue, there was nowhere else to go except back outside into the cold. You were half considering it, but then a cold drop of liquid fell onto the back of your head. Then another, and another, and then the heavens opened. Groaning, you went into the cafeteria and took a seat at the end of the semi-circle.

         When you got to the form room, your brain was aching. You were terrible at maths at the best of times, but to have had it sprung on you so early was practically a war crime. Nobody could be having a worse morning than you. But then there she was. Ms Holsten. Radiant at ever, she was sat at her desk, coolly flipping through a magazine. You walked over to her, ignoring Jimmy calling over to you from the back of the class.

         ‘Hi, Ms Holsten,’ you said in an attempt at a cool voice.

         She looked away from her magazine, looked at you for a brief second, then went back to reading her magazine. ‘Good morning, Tim. Please, go take your seat.’

         As you stood there, awkwardly, not knowing what to do at the lack of acknowledgement, Jimmy came running over and grabbed you by the shoulder.

         ‘Come on, Tim, stop standing up here or people are going to think you’re a teacher’s pet,’ he grinned as he pulled you to the back of the room. When he got you there, he bundled you into a seat, then glanced around nervously as he pulled his seat closer to yours.

         ‘Tim, you’re going to think I’m mental,’ he said in a voice so low you could barely hear him. ‘But Ms Holsten…she’s not human.’

         You stared at Jimmy, and he seemed to interpret your look as incredulity as he hurriedly started whispering again:

         ‘I mean it! She’s not human, or she’s a witch or something, I saw her over the weekend and she-’

         ‘Alright, class,’ Ms Holsten’s voice rang out over the general din of the classroom. Jimmy seized up and pushed his chair back to its normal position. ‘Time for the register.’

         Jimmy’s voice was a squeak when he answered Holsten calling out his name and when she finished the register, he immediately resumed his conversation.

         ‘I saw her go into my mum.’

         ‘You saw her do what?’ Of course, you knew where this was going, but you couldn’t let Jimmy know that you knew.

         ‘Do you remember on Friday; you came over to my house and my mum sent me to my room?’ Jimmy’s eyes kept darting to the front of the classroom. ‘It was after you’d left. There I was, playing some FIFA on the PS4, just about to beat Barca, when I…blacked out, or something. I don’t know what happened except that it had been half six and then it was suddenly nearly ten. It was really bizarre. My tv was still on, and the PlayStation and the game, but they were different teams and it was only just the start of the match.’

         Jimmy stopped as he, again, looked over to the front of the class. Your eyes followed his and saw Holsten still sat there, reading her magazine.

         ‘So, I went to myself “I must be losing my mind”, and I went to find my mum just to, you know, vent about how strange it was, when I saw her.’

         ‘You saw your mum?’

         ‘No, you idiot, I saw Holsten.’ Jimmy’s shoulders were shaking ever so slightly now. ‘She was stood behind my mum, this huge, weird grin on her face, and then she vanished, and my mum did a sort of spasm and then the weird grin was suddenly on my mum’s face. Then my mum got up, put her coat on and went out. She didn’t come back until Sunday afternoon and she either wouldn't tell us or she didn't know where she’d been or what she’d been doing.’

         ‘My dad was livid. He’s always looking for any sign that she’ll go back to her “old ways” as he calls it, they had a massive row and then she left again. She’s staying at my aunts’ now. Meanwhile, my dad has been non-stop crying about the whole thing. He doesn’t realise that his raised voice is like being blasted by the subwoofer at a Rammstein concert. Meanwhile, I could tell them what I saw, what happened, but neither of them would ever believe me and probably have me committed or something.’

         Jimmy’s shoulder’s slumped as he fell into the back of his chair. You looked at the forlorn look on your friend’s face, and then to the front of the class where Holsten was still reading her magazine, cool as you like. You could tell him what you know and maybe confront her, or keep it a secret and carry on with this.
1522112221.title: Your friend, Jimmy

choices: Holsten tells you about her weekend
Holsten brushes it off for now and the school day continues
15221122211.content:
‘You know what,’ you said to yourself. ‘I’ve had a crappy morning, when I thought was going to be a great one after what she said to me on Friday, I’m going to confront her that and help Jimmy in the process.

          ‘Come on,’ you say as you hoist your friend up to his feet. ‘Let’s find out what’s going on.’

          ‘What, you mean you believe me?’ His eyes were red and watery.

          ‘I mean,’ you played it off nonchalantly, mixing lies with truth. ‘I’m not saying that I one hundred per cent believe you, but I did notice something off about your mum the other day on that drive home.’

          ‘What can we do though,’ Jimmy whispered loudly. ‘If she suspects us, won’t she just take us over or something. Possess us?’

          ‘We’re in school, mate, she can’t do anything to us here.’

          ‘Yeah, but what about outside?’ Jimmy retorted, but you were already dragging him up to the front of the class. Ms Holsten peered over the top of her magazine and you could see a slight smirk dancing on her lips.

          You and Jimmy stood in front of her desk.

          ‘Um, miss,’ you said, ‘do you mind if the two of us have a word with you?’

          Ms Holsten tutted and put her magazine down, ‘The one time, other than lunch, that you don’t have to talk to or be talked at by teachers, and you want to talk with a teacher? Most unlike you two.’

          ‘Yes, well, can we talk anyway? In private,’ you replied.

          She looked at you, then at Jimmy, then back at you again. She gave a little shrug and pointed to the door.

          ‘Come on, we’ll go talk in my office,’ she said to the two of you. Then she turned to the rest of the class, ‘Keep the noise down and make sure you get to your classes on time when the bell rings. I will be checking punctuality with the other teachers.’

          ‘Let’s go,’ she said as she led the two of you away to her office.

You’d never been inside of a teacher’s office before and it was not at all what you expected. There were stacks upon stacks of overflowing papers and books over very nearly every inch of the small space. Coffee mugs were strewn around the place, some under the desk, others perched precariously on high shelves. A small, forlorn potted plant rested by the only windowpane which was a thin strip of glass near the ceiling. The only place free of detritus were the two chairs, one behind the desk, and one in front of. She gestured to the latter chair and smiled apologetically:

          ‘Sorry, I only have room for the one spare,’ she flopped herself down into the chair behind the desk. ‘You’ll have to fight amongst yourselves for who gets to sit.’

          You looked at Jimmy who just shook his head at you and gestured for you to sit down. Shrugging at his response, you sat down and Ms Holsten beamed beatifically at the two of you.

          ‘So,’ she said. ‘What is it that the two of you wanted to talk to me about?’

          Jimmy was rocking back and forth on his feet now. You’d seen him get stressed out about tests or particularly important soccer games, but this was a whole other level. If he didn’t calm down fast, something in his head was going to pop, you could tell. Ms Holsten who was still smiling her sweet, pacifying smile. You knew then that she was the only one who could stop Jimmy getting worked up now, but you didn’t like how it was going to be done.

          ‘He knows,’ you said flatly.

          ‘Yeah,’ Jimmy said, hotly. ‘I know all about your crazy possession powers and what you did to my mum! And also…’ Jimmy’s voice faltered.

          ‘Tim…’ Jimmy backed up against the door, his voice cracked. ‘You knew about it, about her, before I told you, didn’t you?’

          You nodded almost imperceptibly, and Jimmy opened his mouth to scream but before he could even breath in, Holsten had turned invisible and rushed into the young man’s body. It shivered slightly as Holsten took control, then the body was completely still. Jimmy’s green eyes, just like his mothers, had turned blue.

          Holsten lumbered around the desk in Jimmy’s body. She collapsed onto her chair and rubbed Jimmy’s short hair.

          ‘This is all a bit of a mess….’ She said apologetically.

          ‘You’re telling me,’ you said, a little more forcefully than you meant to. ‘We were supposed to leave the O’Connor’s house. It was your idea to do so and now Jimmy’s telling me that you were in his mother almost the entire weekend.’

          Holsten grinned sheepishly, ‘Okay, so, let me tell you what happened.’

          ‘You’d just left, and I was watching you go, still in Carol’s body, when it occurred to me, “What if she wakes up and my memory trick hadn’t worked on her? What if she remembered you being in the house when she woke up, paralyzed, with her son’s teacher popping out the back of her head?” We’d both be sunk in that event, but then I remembered that there was an easy way to test her memory, there was another person in the house.’

          'So, I put Carol to bed, just like I said, then I messed around with her memories a bit, I don’t know if I can delete memories outright, so instead, I just filled the memory with other bits of nonsense. A talking giraffe, a robot fighting a centaur, her first love telling her that Tuesday is the soup of the moon and that’s special to them. Just, really weird stuff so that there was no way that she could think it was a real memory.’

          She leant forward, ‘Then, I left her body, turned myself into my ghost form, and I went into Jimmy’s room. He was playing one of those football games on his PlayStation, and I just popped myself right into his body. I waited a couple of minutes and went to his mother’s room, where she’d only just woken up. I could tell it had worked right away, she was lying in bed, an unlit cigarette clasped between her fingers, and she had this look of intense concentration on her face.’

          ‘“What’s up, mum?” I asked her, “You look like you had a bad dream.”

          And she frowned for a minute, then looked up at me and said, “I don’t know if it was bad or not, it was more weird than anything else. Really, really weird.” And that was me satisfied. I went back to Jimmy’s room and it was my full intent to just leap right out of him then and there and go ahead with my original plan, which, by the way, I’m not telling you, yet.’ She grinned a troublemaking grin which did not look all that much out of place on Jimmy’s face, you had to admit.

          ‘But then I saw the poster he had of that footballer, Karen Carney.’

          ‘Oh god,’ you interjected. ‘Jimmy has a massive crush on her. I don’t see it, but he basically wants to marry her.’

          ‘That’s putting it mildly,’ Holsten laughed. ‘She isn’t my thing at all, either. In fact, “she’s” generally speaking aren’t, but at the moment, seeing her in that poster and Jimmy’s hormones overwhelmed me. Hell, even now, just talking about it is in his body again is starting to get me going. Maybe it’s the difference between genders or experience or something, but it’s an even stronger effect than his mother’s libido had had on me. Before I could properly comprehend what was going on, I was sat at his computer desk, poring through his saved links and downloaded files, all the while stroking my new penis fast and furious.’

          You cringed hard and turned away, ‘Come on, please, I don’t need to hear this.’

          ‘Come on is what I did alright,’ Holsten laughed. ‘It was even stronger than a normal impulse is because this was almost like a first time for him. A woman’s mind was controlling his hand so it was like a stranger was gripping his penis and combined with knowledge of exactly how he liked to do it….’

          ‘Jesus,’ was all you could say.

          ‘I don’t think Jesus would’ve approved at any of this, to be honest.…That said, the whole thing was other in like, a minute? Maybe less. Jimmy’s body orgasmed that fast. It got absolutely everywhere. I was tempted to just edit the memory and leave him to deal with it. But I decided to be nice and clean it up.’

          ‘And then you went downstairs and possessed his mum again?’

          ‘That one,’ she trailed off and was silent for a while. ‘I’d just finished cleaning up the spunk when I heard his mother leaving her bedroom. She’d been in there all night and I realised that before I left for the evening, I really wanted to have one last cigarette.’

          ‘I know, I know,’ she waved her hands as you raised your eyebrows at her. ‘I know, I know, Helen Holsten, addicted to cigarettes, crazy eh? Though truthfully, I think I could only really stomach them whilst I’m possessing a smoker. I mean, I don’t want to get my actual body addicted to them. All the benefits, none of the negatives, right? Anyway, I went in, and it was just like earlier with Jimmy. Apparently, she’d also been masturbating and she’d been going at it for the last couple of hours. She’d come down to get a glass of water and just happened to mistime it because I was there. I grabbed her purse and coat and was out of the door in two seconds flat.’

         ‘Yeah, that’s how Jimmy found out about you,’ you said. ‘He saw you going into his mother and then leaving. He says you were gone, or at least, she was gone, for pretty much two nights straight.’

         ‘Yeah,’ she grinned awkwardly, about that…’
15221122211.title: Confront Ms Holsten (either with or without Jimmy)

152211222111.content:
It was a look you’d seen on Jimmy’s face many a time. Shifty eyes, slightly reddened cheeks, the thin sheen of sweat; all the trademark traits of Jimmy feeling guilty over something. Only it wasn’t Jimmy who was guilty of anything at all, it was Holsten.
‘The truth is,’ she was even pausing like Jimmy usually did at such moments. Stretching out the admission. ‘The truth is that I may have went out to a bar, or two, or three, and gotten Mrs Carol O’Connor ever so slightly tipsy and, well, now, she might get a few strange looks at a few of the bars and clubs in town.’

         ‘What do you mean by that?’ You asked.

         ‘Well,’ Holsten put an emphasis on elongating the consonants, again, stretching them out. ‘I, um, totally by accidentally, ended up naked in Tech Noir.’

         The image of Carol O’Connor’s lithe, pale skinned body, completely naked, with her long tresses of red hair cascading around her youthfully buoyant breasts as she danced wildly in the strobe lights of a club, suddenly sprung into your mind. You could picture her so vividly you could see the flecks of sweat falling from her body, you could swear you could even smell the musk.

         ‘Oi, that’s my mother you’re thinking of with that thing,’ Holsten said with a chuckle, pointing at your throbbing erection.

         ‘I, no, it’s just-’ you stammered, which just made Holsten laugh even harder.

         ‘It’s alright, Timmy boy,’ she said in a mock soothing voice. ‘I’d wager if I were in any other male body right now but this one and remembering this night then I’d be in a similar situation.’

         You couldn’t do anything but give a conciliatory grunt as you pulled your shirt over the tent pitched in your pants.

         ‘Anyway,’ Holsten smirked, ‘if that was enough to cause that reaction, I’m kind of intrigued at what will happen when I tell you about the rest of it.’

         ‘There’s more?’

         ‘Of course, there’s more,’ Holsten rolled her eyes. ‘These powers wouldn’t be much use if all I used them for was stripping and smoking.’

         She shifted her weight on the chair before continuing, ‘So, as I was saying, I went to the clubs and ended up stripping, completely divesting myself of my vestments, which, of course, got me kicked out and I think Mrs O’Connor is also barred, but whatever. The next part is kind of fuzzy, my memory of it, I mean, as I was completely and utterly sloshed by this point. I managed to make it to my home, my actual home, that is, and then, just before passing out, I drunkenly thought to myself, “Actually, I want to sleep as myself,” and so I left Carol’s body and when I did, I was completely stone cold sober.

         ‘I didn’t even realise it, at first, I was lightheaded like I normally get after leaving a body, but then that passed, and I was sober. Complete normal. I wasn’t even tired. In fact, I was completely refreshed, as if I’d just woken up from a long, peaceful sleep. I looked at Carol, sleeping there, mumbling and groaning with drunken dreams, and it occurred to me. I never had to deal with that ever again. The negative affects of drinking, or smoking, or drugs, or sex, or anything. Never again. I just borrow a body and use it then dispose of it.’

         Wait, what did Holsten just say? Your eyes widened and the blood began to drain from your face as you realised the severity of what Holsten was saying

         ‘I rolled Carol onto her side, and then I went back to the clubs,’ Holsten continued, not noticing your growing discomfort. ‘I spent the rest of the night hopping from one body to the next. From one of the guys doing cocaine in the toilets of one club, to maid of honour in the hen party in the next.’

         She suddenly leaned over the desk and looked you deep in the eyes.

         ‘You’d have loved my favourite of the night though,’ she said in an oddly flat, yet serious voice. ‘She looked the spitting image of that girl you like, Tracey, only more grown up. Grown out, if you know what I mean.’

         She moved even closer, not breaking eye contact.

         ‘She was on a work night out, her first one, she’d only just started at the place a couple of weeks ago,’ Holsten looked feverish as she spoke. Beads of sweat dropped from her forehead into her eyes, but she didn’t wipe them away or even blink. ‘She was crushing hard on a guy there. He was painfully average looking, but she was heads over heels for him. He was married though. I felt sorry for the little thing though, so, I switched to his body, and then I fucked her seven ways from Sunday in the toilets.’

         You tried to push yourself away from her staring gaze, but the chair was caught on the carpet and wouldn’t move.

         ‘As I was thrusting into her, I thought to myself, what if I actually did thrust myself into her?’ Specks of spittle and foam were building up around her mouth as she spoke. ‘The first time I ejaculated, I shot not just my cum into her, I shot myself into her. I switched bodies mid orgasm, and he just carried on pumping away. He was completely caught up in a moment of lust. When she came and the spasms shot through me, I jumped back into his body and went again. Back and forth I went, riding the crest of the orgasmic wave each time I did. And all the time, all I could think about was that I can’t wait to do that with-’

         Almost as if something snapped inside of her, her face slackened then, and her eyes drooped a little. She slid back over the desk and into her seat.

         ‘Anyway,’ she said on, her voice was back to normal, ‘then I left and went home. Mrs O’Connor was still sleeping away and I let her be until the afternoon came. Then, as soon as she woke up, I jumped into her, rearranged some memories, deleting some, changing others, and then took some heavy-duty sleeping pills to knock her out until she’d gotten over the hangover she’d woken up with. Then I walked her home the next day and left her to deal with that whole mess that Jimmy was upset about.’

         She finally noticed your pale, worried face.

         ‘Tim?’ She said in a questioning tone. ‘You look ill, what’s wrong?’

         You gulped nervously and decided to…
152211222111.title: Holsten tells you about her weekend

1522112221111.content:
‘It’s nothing,’ you said, clambering to your feet and making for the door. ‘It’s just that I remembered I have something that my mum asked me to do for her and I haven’t done it, so, I have to hurry and do it.’

         Holsten looked at you with a bemused expression on her face. Finally, she rolled her eyes and sighed, ‘Go on then, mama’s boy.’

         You nodded and quickly left her office. You didn’t risk looking back until you were at the far end of the corridor. Of course, you thought to yourself, she could be in her ghost form right now, hovering over you, and you’d never even know. You pulled your jacket closer around yourself and half walked, half ran, out of the school building. It wasn’t until you were out on the street that you realised that you’d just put Jimmy into a dangerous situation with Ms Holsten, again, and just left him, again. You felt a wave of nausea course through you. But what could you have done? What could you do now?

         You were so preoccupied with your thoughts that you didn’t even realise you’d bumped into someone until they pushed you back and a gravelly voice angrily muttered, ‘Watch it!’

         Standing in front of you was one of the more notorious local vagrants, you remembered his name as you began to apologise.

         ‘Sorry, I’m so sorry, Jezzer,’ you stammered.

         ‘As well you should be,’ Jezzer said gruffly. As you made to walk away, he suddenly reached out and grabbed ahead of you by the shoulders. He pulled you face to face with him. As he ran his rheum filled eyes over you, you tried to pull away, but, with surprising strength in his bony fingers, he held you firmly in place.

         Just as you were about to scream, he released you and stepped back, then said, ‘You have your mother’s eyes.’

         This statement was so surreal, so out of place, that you just stood there, mouth agape, looking at the man in his tattered, filthy clothing, and could find nothing to say.

         ‘See, her eyes are blue,’ Jezzer muttered, more to himself then you.

         This nonplussed you even further. Yours, and your mother’s eyes, were hazel, not blue. Also, what was Jezzer talking about, and how did he know the colour of your mum’s eyes?

         ‘Because I see things,’ Jezzer said abruptly, startling you. ‘No one pays any attention to the crazy homeless guy, and that’s why I can notice things the rest of you don’t notice.’

         Could Jezzer read minds or something?

         ‘Here,’ Jezzer said, pointing down the road. ‘Follow me, we need to talk about your “little problem”.’

         ‘My little problem?’ You asked.

         ‘I’m talking about that teacher of yours, the one who can possess other people,’ Jezzer snapped as he turned and began to stride away.

         ‘Wait? The fuck-How do you know about that!?’

         Jezzer stopped for a moment, then barked out a short laugh, ‘Follow me and find out.’ Then he marched away down the street. After a few moments of indecision, you hurried after him.
1522112221111.title: Make an excuse and leave, you find help in an u...

15221122211111.content:
You hadn’t been to this part of town before, but you knew that it had a less than savoury reputation and you could see why. Every house you passed was either boarded up or had every window smashed and was falling apart, shaken to pieces by the rumble of the trainline which ran overhead. Graffiti was adorned every wall, it seemed. Some of the street art could actually, conceivably, be called “True Art” with its impressive, proper attention paid to form and function and being detailed with vivid colours and intricate designs which would instill a feeling of hope in even the stoniest of hearts. Most of it, however, was just racial or sexual epithets, lazily scrawled.

         A few people were milling about the street you were following Jezzer down. They were dressed almost as shabbily as the man himself, but were as Jezzer was striding with purpose, these people were milling about listlessly, as though they were only walking because if they stopped, they might not remember how to start again. Swirls of rubbish caught in the wind surrounded them, but whenever a piece would hit them, they didn’t even seem to notice. Most of them didn’t look at you, but in the eyes of the few who did, you could barely recognise any liveliness, any humanity in them. For all the world, they seemed dead.

         It wasn’t until you reached a small, hastily put together shanty that Jezzer finally spoke again.

         ‘Hmph,’ he snorted, wiping his nose with a crusty sleeve. ‘Welcome to my humble abode.’

         He pushed open the door to his home and walked in. It was almost pitch black inside the wooden shelter, more a large shed than a house, and not a very well put together one at that. You’d already followed the strange man to the strange part of town, and now he was inviting you into his strange home, which was pitch black, you couldn’t even see Jezzer in there…was it wise to carry on with this?
‘Come on,’ Jezzer growled from somewhere inside the building. ‘You’re letting the cold in.’

         You gulped. With one tentative foot forward, you entered Jezzer’s home. As you entered the building, you still couldn’t see Jezzer. You inched your way forward, until your foot hit something solid. In that very same instant, there was a sudden fwoosh as a brazier in the middle of the room, the brazier you’d just walked into, suddenly sparked to life. You jumped backwards as the heat from the fire tried to envelop you. From behind the brazier, a kneeling Jezzer was fumbling with flue, eventually making the fire much smaller.

         ‘Sorry,’ he said, almost bashfully. ‘The damned thing has always been temperamental. Can barely trust it at all. Which, with the wooden décor and all, means I can’t leave it. Makes sleeping in the winter a real bitch, I can tell you that for nothing.’

         He pointed at a turned over milk crate.

         ‘Have a seat,’ he said in a mock courteous voice. Then, without checking to see whether you’d actually sat down or not, he turned his back and started rooting around in a large, nearby trunk. Compared to the rest of the shelter, the trunk looked extremely expensive and very well made. The leather straps on it, though frayed from age, looked like genuine leather, and the case of the trunk looked to be made from some type of oak and bound with metal. You suddenly had the image of Jezzer being some kind of vagrant pirate king, with his treasure chest, his ragged beard, and his belligerent nature. Who knows, maybe he was at some point in his life.

         As you were thinking this, Jezzer had pulled something from the trunk and had walked over to his own chair, which, when you looked closer, you could see was a shopping trolley which had had the back and wheels removed, and a cheap mattress used as the cushioning. Jezzer leaned back in his makeshift throne and, further enhancing your piratical view of him, revealed the bottle of rum he had plundered from his chest. He took a lengthy swig and smacked his lips as he swallowed. Then he took a second, then a third, and then a fourth.

         ‘Her name was Ronnie, Veronica, if you want to get biblical,’ he said without any preamble.

         ‘Whose name?’ It was really the only question you could ask.

         ‘You think I was always like this, boy,’ Jezzer said, waving his arms at his surroundings. ‘Do you think us homeless folk are just born homeless?’

         ‘I don’t, I mean, what?’

         ‘Well, some of us are,’ Jezzer pinched the bridge of his nose and took another glug from his bottle. ‘I don’t envy them poor bastards; I’ll tell you that for nothing.’

         ‘But most of us,’ he stopped as his eyes welled with tears. ‘No, most of us have something go wrong in their lives. Loss of a job, injury, death of a loved one. I was blessed enough to have all three of those things, and even more.’

         He finished the bottle and threw it into a corner. Your eyes followed the flying bottle and watched it land in a small mountain of previously emptied bottles. You turned back to Jezzer whose face was now slicked with tears and snot. He sniffed and wiped his face, again with the same crusty sleeve as earlier, he seemed to steel himself as he pulled another bottle of rum from within his coat.

         ‘Her name was Ronnie, and she found that damned stone, thirty years ago.’
15221122211111.title: Storytime with Jezzer (reserved)

152211222111111.content:
‘We’d been seeing each other for three years by that point,’ Jezzer said, the bottle of rum held before him, but he hadn’t drunk from it yet. It hovered just below his chin as he spoke.

         ‘I’d just finished my undergrad in law and was interning at the local solicitors. Ambulance chasers, really, and whilst I had had many offers, far, far better ones as I’d graduated top of my class, I’d turned them all down for Ronnie.’

         ‘She was special kind of girl. Gentle. She had the kind of beauty that can only come from continuous and serene kindness. I don’t know what she ever saw in me, the prosecutor. She didn’t want to move to the big city where all my offers had come from, she liked it here, and she was about to start her veterinary nursing course.’ He smiled a half smile as his eyes wettened once more. ‘I’d tried to talk her out of it. She loved animals so much. She was even vegetarian, which was a big deal back then. “You know one of the big parts of being a vet is putting animals down, right?” I told her. She didn’t care though, just wanted to save the ones she could. As many as she could.’

         The hand which was holding the bottle of rum trembled, sloshing a small amount of the liquid over his shirt. Jezzer didn’t even seem to notice.

         ‘She found the stone in Parson’s field,’ Jezzer basically spat the location’s name. ‘It was a Sunday, last one of August, and we were just coming home from a walk. We heard some animal crying, it sounded hurt and she wanted to look for it, to make sure it was alright, to help it.’

         Jezzer raised the bottle to his lips and when he took it away again, half the contents of the bottle were gone down his gullet.

         ‘We couldn’t agree on where the cry was coming from, she said left, I said right, and so we decided the smart thing to be would be to split up and look. After only a couple of minutes, I’d found it, of course, it was to the right of the field, just as I’d said it was. I picked the thing up carefully as I could and went to look for Ronnie. I found her crouched over, holding a strange looking stone. “Hey, I was right about where to look. I’ve found the injured animal, it was a bird. A blue jay, I think it is. What’s that you got there?” I asked her. She had this faraway look in her eyes.’

         ‘Then she looked up at me and then back to the stone, then to the bird, and she dropped the stone. “Oh,” she said, “it was weird, but I thought that that stone was glowing or something. But when I picked it up, I saw it was just a normal stone.” And that was that, we forgot about the stone, all our attention was on the bird, which we took home and which we, mostly Ronnie, nursed back to health.’

         Jezzer looked glumly at the half empty bottle in his hands.

         ‘It was a couple of days after that when it started. I was just getting back from the office when Ronnie practically skipped up to me at the front door. “Oh, Jeremy, you’ll never guess what I found out I can do today!” She said in a singsong voice. We had a light-hearted back and forth but then she suddenly disappeared, right as I was looking at her. “Ronnie? Ronnie?!” I called out. I went from room to room, frantically searching for her, but she was nowhere. She’d literally vanished right in front of me and I had no idea what to do about it. I walked back to the living room, about to call the police, though I had no idea what I would even say, when I saw the injured bird perched on the windowsill, watching me. It had been in the spare room ever since we’d brought it home, but now it was here, and it was looking at me with an almost unnerving degree of cognisance. It opened its beak and started chirping, only it sounded more like laughing. I stood there, telephone receiver in hand, thinking I was going mad, when the bird gave a little shudder, and then Ronnie was stood in front of me, as if nothing had happened.

         ‘“Ta-da!” She said, waving her arms like she'd just done a magic trick. I asked her what was going on, where had she gone, and she just laughed and told me that she had been the bird. I honestly felt like I’d misheard her, so I asked again, and she just rolled her eyes and said, “Watch, the bird will fly over there, then look at you.” And then, poof! She was gone again, and the bird flew over to where Ronnie had said it would, and then it looked at me, and then it shuddered, and Ronnie was back again.’

         ‘I asked her how she did that, and more importantly, how did she keep vanishing. “I already told you, silly, I was the bird.” She laughed as she vanished again, and the bird started flying in circles around my head like it was some damned cartoon. Over the next few months, there were other demonstrations of her new ability, some cats here, a few dogs there, there was also a particularly memorable day at the zoo, but compared to what I saw later on, with her and other people, it was so incredibly carefree and breezy that you never would think anything bad would ever come of it. Of course, I thought about misusing the power, I-we could've made a lot of money with it. But she'd smiled that smile of hers and said no, and that was that.’

         Wait, you thought to yourself, other people? What else does Jezzer know? Before you could ask, however, Jezzer continued.

         ‘But then,’ Jezzer’s face hardened. ‘That’s when that arse-boil Jackson bought out the veterinary practice Ronnie was working part time at.’
152211222111111.title: Ronnie's Story (reserved)

1522112221111111.content:
You've probably heard of the Jacksons,' Jezzer wiped some spittle from the side of his mouth with his sleeve. 'They used to be a big deal 'round these parts. Still kinda are, I guess, but back in the day, their family name was feared.'

         You had heard of the Jacksons. There was a kid in your school, Philip Jackson, who nobody went near because strange things always seemed to happen to his family or to his friends.

         'They came from old money. Really old money. And, like any old money, most of it was dirty. The first Jackson who made it big did so on the back of slaves and since then the state of the family's soul ain't improved much.' Jezzer spat a gob of phlegm onto the fire, where it sizzled and popped. He almost seemed pleased with the noise before the frown returned to his face.

         'They were into everything from arson to extortion, even murder, if you believe the rumours. Which you should. But the Jackson who caused all the problems, for me, for Ronnie, for his whole damn family, was Barry Jackson.'

         Amazingly, Jezzer had yet another bottle of rum concealed with his own coat. He popped the top and took a few mouthfuls.

         'The Jacksons were evil, sure,' Jezzer's words were beginning to sound slurred, ' but they were smart. All of them, incredible minds, and all the more dangerous for that. It was hell for the law to make anything stick to them. They had a way of talking, of wording statements, that could twist most people into pretzel shapes. And everything was done through an intermediary. There was always at least two degrees of separation between the crime and them, the criminal.

         Barry Jackson, though, was not like the rest. He was as cruel, sure, as evil as the others. But he absolutely lacked the wits of his clan. The others were surgeons in their criminality, Barry was the homeopathic huckster. He made the family money, which is why they tolerated him, his fuck ups, but then he went and got arrested with no plausible avenues of denial.

         He was caught selling bad meat to local schools. Caught literally red handed. When the police had raided the warehouse, the idiot had had a bloody chicken carcass in each hand and was using them as puppets in a macabre comedy act. I was asked to work as the prosecutor for the case and I took it eagerly.' Jezzer winced as he said the last sentence. He breathed heavily for a moment and seemed to be holding back tears.

         'No one else wanted the case,' Jezzer said, his voice cracking. 'That should've been a red flag right there. But I was desperate for something resembling a real case. I was tired of the petty disputes, the vehicle claims, the outstanding bills. I wanted something real, something I would have, that I could have had in the big city. I wanted it....'

         'I won the case,' Jezzer said into his chest. 'Of course I did. I was a good lawyer back then, and even if I hadn't had been, it was as much of a slam dunk as anything could be. Jackson got a year's sentence and a fine, I can't remember how much, maybe 80 thou, it doesn't really matter. The point that did matter was that I had slighted their family name and so, a few months after the case, Barry Jackson strolled up to Ronnie's vet surgery and bought the thing outright.'

         Jezzer took another mouthful of his drink. 'He played it up, at first, to the media I mean. Said he was looking to atone for his misdeeds and that looking after animals after he had so mistreated them was the best way. I saw right away what he was doing and I tried to warn Ronnie but she had shook her head and said "People can change." She'd believed him. Things carried on as normal for a few months, and I almost started to believe myself. I even met Barry a few times, and even though I came away from each of those meetings feeling like I needed a long shower, I started believing myself.'

         'And then, one Thursday morning in November, I got a phone call from Ronnie. She sounded frantic, crazed almost. I tried to get her to calm down, but she was practically gibbering. I told her to wait and I rushed to the vets but she was gone. And so were all the animals. I later found out that Jackson had had them all, the dogs, the cats, the rabbits and whatever else, whether they healthy and unhealthy, all of them were incinerated overnight. He'd planned to have it blamed on Ronnie. He was really after me, because I prosecuted against him, and he'd gone through Ronnie to do so.....'

         'He succeeded in that regard...'Jezzer smiled sadly. 'I lost Ronnie in more ways than one that day. I never saw her again. She went missing and this helped prop up Jackson's fiction. He told everyone that she'd gone crazy and killed all the animals under her care in a pique of madness.' Jezzer's sad smile twisted into a cruel sneer. 'I lost Ronnie, but three days after Jackson's plot, he was found dead on the outskirts of town. Apparently, he'd been walking his dogs when one of them had gone feral and attacked him. The puzzling thing is that the creature had taken its time to kill the man. He'd died when the dog had bitten clean through his windpipe, but the autopsy had found that the man had lived for hours, slowly bleeding to death, after the tendons in his legs had been ripped out by the dog. Then, over many hours, the dog had stripped bits of flesh from the man. Had carefully and methodically removed the man's skin, and even crushed the bones in the man's hands so he couldn't drag himself back to town.'

         Jezzer drained the last of his rum and threw the empty bottle against the wall. 'Most people thought it had to be a rival gang hit, or something along those lines. It couldn't have been the work of an animal...and they would be half right, at least. "People can change", she'd said...."People can change"....'

         He sighed wearily and then pushed himself forward and vomited spectacularly over the floor. You jumped backwards to avoid the spew but even so, some flecks of the bile found its way onto your shoes.

         'Sorry,' Jezzer grinned sheepishly, before frowning once again. 'It wasn't the last time I saw that power though, or the accursed stone behind it. Ten years after I'd lost Ronnie, I saw the same thing happening again. By this time, Parson's field had been built over, that building still stands to this day. Your teacher's future apartment, Gardener's Heights...'

15221122211111111.content:
'Course,' Jezzer paused to hock some phlegm into the fire. 'She wasn't the first person to move into those apartments. No, there were others before her. You've probably heard of, heh, one of them, the Parson's cult?'

         The name sounded familiar to you but you couldn't remember where you'd heard it. Jezzer saw the quizzical look on your face and snorted.

         'Makes sense that, actually,' he sniffed. 'A real black mark on the history of this town. Not a surprise that you've not heard of it.'

         Your jaw dropped as he pulled yet another bottle from deep within the recesses of his coat.

         'See, it was called the Parson's cult because it was assumed that everyone within that building belonged to some kind of cult. A murdering cult. On Parson's Field? Them media people are smart, aren't they? Anyway, these were people who you wouldn't look at twice in the street, all working respectable jobs, some of them very active members of the communities and churches. And yet, the bodies started turning up. All with their fingerprints. All with their DNA lacing the insides, I'll let you imagine how. All from within that apartment. Except for one resident, that is....a small, mousey man, Reggie Forthing.'

         'Of course, it was him who found the stone on this occasion,' Jezzer laughed grimly. 'He was an assistant clerk at a rival law firm. I knew him, kind of. He desperately wanted to get onto the prosecution team, but he was beyond mediocre. Had fluked his way through law school, barely passing, and there was little money to be made in barely passing. And then the people above him started dying. One by one, the team above him quit the mortal coil. He was suspected, of course. Hell, we were all suspects, but there was no evidence to be found against him. They found loads of evidence against his neighbours, however. Every single one of them had, apparently, been involved in some grand conspiracy to get their friend and beloved neighbour, Reggie, promoted beyond his capabilities, and increasingly, knowingly, smug about it. They all denied knowledge of their crimes, of course, even though not a single one of them could give a concrete alibi on where they were at the times of each murder.'

         Jezzer sighed wearily, 'Several of them were sent to death row, others committed suicide, and some just went missing. Reggie himself, well, the remains of his body were found a few weeks after the initial story broke. Accidental death, it was ruled, he'd fell asleep whilst smoking, caught fire and died. People thought that those apartments were cursed for years, it's why they were so cheap to rent. Having said all that, personally, I think he might still be out there, Reggie, I mean. I think that he killed off his original body and is now hopping from body to body, committing murders where he can. Or maybe he died when his body died, I don't claim to know how this stone thing works.'

         'How do you know it was Reggie?' You asked.

         Jezzer looked at you with a bleary eye before shrugging. 'To be honest, I don't, it could have been one of the other residents, but I just saw this incredibly reserved person suddenly break out of their shell whilst everything started working out for them because of some brutal murders that just happened to be sourced from a place where I'd seen a similarly tragic event previously. It could have been someone else, but my money is on Reggie.'

15221122211111112.content:
Holsten knew that she wasn't thinking clearly. For the past few days, it was as though a fog had lodged itself in her brain, and she could see the shapes of thoughts, but they lacked any clear detail. That is, unless those thoughts were about Tim Gately. Then they were crystal clear.

         He had just been here, in her office. She'd been telling him about her weekend as....as.....Tim's friend, Jimmy? Oh! She'd been Jimmy's mother....Vanessa? Cathy? Holsten couldn't remember the woman's name. She remembered the sex. She remembered the cigarettes. She remembered teasing Tim as he struggled to hide his hard on in the back of the car. Other details were lacking, however. She needed to find Tim so she could start....brain....working.....thinking! Yes, so that she could start thinking again. She stood up to follow after Tim, who had only just left her office, but her eyes narrowed as she realized that she was too tall. Oh, right, she was still in Tim's friend, Jimmy. She peeled herself from his form and he crumpled to a heap on the floor. She glanced down at the boy, apathy scored on her face, then she turned into her spirit form and flew after her Tim.

         She found him following the vagrant, Jezzer. What was he doing in such disreputable company. No. This would never do. As disturbing a thought as it was, she would have to take over the vagrant's body, and force him to scare her Tim away. Yes, that would be the best course of action. She ran until she was parallel to the old man, then turned 90 degrees and ran directly at him. She was expecting the soft, warm feeling of sinking into another person's body, so when, instead, she ran into an iron cold wall, she fell flat on her invisible ass.

         That had hurt, Really, really hurt. She shook her head and looked up at the old man. What had happened, why had she been repelled from entering his body. Maybe it was just a fluke? She stood up, dusted herself down, and tried a second time. Same result. Though this time, she went flying backwards and landed in a pile of garbage. The old vagrant looked in her direction. She had the uncanny feeling that he knew she was there. Maybe he couldn't see her, but he knew she was there. She got up to try a third time but then thought better of it. Being this close to Tim, the fog lifted a little, and she was starting to think more clearly again.

         'Whatever the reason is, I can't take over this man's body,' she muttered to herself. 'Maybe I could take over of the other derelicts in the area and scare Tim away that way....no....the old man could just protect him, and maybe even kick me out of their bodies anyway.....hmm....No, I think the smart thing to do would be to go and wait for Tim somewhere where I know he'll turn up sooner or later.'

         She looked thoughtful for a moment, then grinned a wide and toothy grin. She zoomed away and within minutes, she was standing in front of Tim's house. She drifted slowly into the house and went from room to room until, finally, she found....

152211222111111121.content:
It was almost midnight by the time Tim got home that night. Jezzer had kept telling drunken story after drunker about the mysterious stones and the affect they had on the people who found them. Tim wasn't entirely sure whether he believed all the stories, it was Jezzer after all, but still, he did believe that something had happened to his teacher. He absentmindedly brushed the iron cross in his trouser's pocket which Jezzer had insisted he take for self defence. He couldn't decide which was the more insane thing to discover today, that his teacher had become a body stealing sex junkie, or that the town's most infamous homeless drunkard was a font of practical knowledge regarding the former's condition. Still, that was a worry for the morning, Tim still had to decide on a course of action, and he felt as though he owed it to Jimmy to involve him in the planning of.....what plan? What could he, Tim, actually do to stop Holsten?

         For, he realised now, she had to be stopped. He'd been torn between loving what was happening, and being terrifyingly disgusted by it, but now he was firmly on the latter side of the coin. Holsten had to be stopped. She'd already messed up the lives of Jimmy's parents, and she was only getting more irrational and erratic as time was going on.

         As he entered his home, he was surprised to found the downstairs of his house was completely dark. Normally, his mother would still be awake, watching television in the living room. A horrible thought entered his mind, what if Holsten was here? He had to investigate. He slipped his shoes off and curled his toes on the carpet. Then, he slowly made his way up the stairs, stepping over and so avoiding the eighth step, which he knew would creak. On tiptoes, he crept over to his mother's room and, slowly, carefully, twisted the knob until the latch just about turned, and he pushed the door open. A thin crack of moonlight was spilling through the curtains. For a moment he stood stock still looking into the room as his eyes adjusted to the gloom. But then there was a great ripping snore and he saw his mother fast asleep in bed.

         'Hmm,' he muttered to himself. 'Well, I can't wake her up just to ask if she's been taken over by the spirit of my sex crazed English teacher....and even if she has, she's just sleeping right now.....I'll check on Heather and Claire and then get some sleep. I can't do anything until morning, it looks like.'

         Tim quietly closed the door and then went to check on his sisters. He wasn't surprised to find them both asleep, Heather usually went to bed pretty early, and Claire, being much younger, went to bed earlier still. He went to his own room and sat down on the edge of his bed and rubbed his temples.

         'This whole thing is so fucked up,' he said under his breath. 'I don't know where she is, or who she is, I only know that she will find me because of some supernatural or maybe extraterrestrial artifact has possessed her just as much as she possesses other people.'

         He lied down on the bed and unzipped his trousers, he kicked them off and then he rolled himself up in the quilt on his bed and then, despite himself and after only a few minutes, he was fast asleep.


'Come on, Tim, if we don't get onto this boat and go into the tunnel, it means that we're not in love, you do love me, don't you?'

It sounded like she was speaking to him from underwater as the boat took them through the hazy pink smoke of the tunnel. Somewhere, a battered speaker was belting out a vaguely romantic muzak tune.

Tim looked at Tracey, who was looking back at him with a look of longing in her eye that he'd not seen in many months.

And we still have't had sex, have we? I lead you on and on and on and on and what did it do? Drive you into the whore, Holsten's arms.'

He opened his eyes and found himself in his bedroom. It had all been a dream. Except...there was someone else there in his room.
